Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 AGT Mentoring Workshop Co-Located with Economics and Computation (EC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support students to attend the Algorithmic Game Theory (AGT) Mentoring Workshop and the 19th Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Conference on Economics and Computation (EC), June 18 - 21, 2018, in Ithaca, NY. The field of Algorithmic Game Theory is at the intersection of theoretical computer science and economics. This makes it most suitable to handle foundational issues posed by tremendous growth in economic and social systems on the Internet, and therefore the field has been thriving in the past few decades. Economics and Computation is the leading conference in this area, with the main aim of strengthening the field by bringing together both computer scientists and economists. The investigators are organizing a one-day AGT mentoring workshop to be co-located with EC.

The workshop will help to mentor and train students pursuing research careers in the field of AGT. Travel funds from NSF will facilitate participants' attendance at the mentoring workshop and EC, where they will learn about current research and interact with leaders in the field. The award will cover travel, lodging and registration fees for approximately 8 to 10 carefully selected students who otherwise would find it difficult to attend. The selection criteria for the travel award and the workshop program will aim to encourage participation by underrepresented minorities and women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 AGT Mentoring Workshop Co-Located with Economics and Computation (EC) was used to support the travel of 15 students to attend the workshop. 


The workshop lasted a full day, and provided both technical and mentoring tutorials. The technical tutorials covered hot topics at this year's EC conference, including Auction Design, Social Choice Theory, Fair Division, and Prophet Inequalities. We also hosted a panel of senior researchers to share their views on current hot topics in Algorithmic Game Theory.


The mentoring sessions included a networking lunch with senior members of the EC community, and a panel discussion on career path advice from senior members of the community. At the end of the day, we also led a session on "creating your public image," which gave advice on how to write reviews, how to target conferences/workshops, and generally what steps help build your image in a research community.


Intellectual Merit: The workshop provided the next generation of students with valuable tools to work in Economics and Computation, and the travel funding enabled students to attend who otherwise would not be able. The topics covered in the technical tutorials were selected to coincide with the current hot topics in Economics and Computation.


Broader Impact: Of the 15 students selected to receive travel grants, six are female, and one belongs to an under-represented minority. The travel grants enabled a diverse group of students who would otherwise be unable to attend EC to participate. In addition, the technical material covered relates directly to major markets in industry such as ad auctions, ridesharing, cloud computing, etc. The technical tutorials helped prepare the students to do research which contributes to these important domains.
